The American Psychiatric Association has rejected [[video game addiction]] as a psychological addiction in their [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] because there has not been much substantial research dealing with this matter, where the effects of gaming cannot be readily discernable or even quantifiable. As the gaming market is increasing steadily over time and becoming more mainstream, the more people can subject themselves to hours of gameplay.
  â   â
==American Psychiatric Association==
  â   â
The American Psychiatric Association came to the conclusion that until further research is done, video game addiction will not be considered a mental disorder that needs medical attention and thus does not fall under the true category of addiction.
  â   â
Since 2003 there has been a progress of the recognition of video game addiction as a real addiction, with more research dedicated to studying its causes and effects.
  â   â
At the 2006 meeting for the [[American Medical Association]] a report based on information from scientific literature from 1985 to 2007, concluded that âthere is currently insufficient research to definitely label video game overuse as an addiction.â However the committee, Council on Science and Public Health, highly suggested that the AMA includes in their next version of the DSM.
  â   â
Dr. Michael Brody, head of a television and media committee at the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, agrees with the AMAâs decision. He believes video game addiction can be at least be symptoms of other disorders such as [[depression]] or [[social anxiety]], which are listed in DSM-IV
  â   â
==Psychological Research==
  â
[[File:Dopamine Pathways.png|thumb|Dopamine pathways become activated when subjects get rewarded in a videogame.]]
  â   â
===Groups Effected===
  â   â
Not everyone who plays an MMORPG develops problematic behaviors or addiction. Although all ages, sexes, and social and cultural groups are susceptible to MMORPG addiction, people born between 1977 and 1997 are most vulnerable.<ref name="amn">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Internet Gaming Addiction| publisher = Armenian Medical Network| date = 2008-05-04| url = http://www.health.am/psy/more/internet-gaming-addiction/| doi = | accessdate = 2011-05-03}}</ref>
  â   â
===Neural Chemical Effect===
  â   â
[[Addiction]] is a psychological disorder that affects the way the brain functions by impacting chemical processes related to motivation, decision making, learning, inhibitory control, and pleasure seeking. Behavioral or soft addictions like gambling and sex are forms of psychological dependence; addictions to substances like drugs and alcohol are forms of both psychological and physical dependence.
  â   â
Scientists have found that the brainâs mesocorticolimbic center which is associated with reward and addiction, becomes activated when the subjects were asked to play a computer game that involved clicking on circles before they reached the opposite side of the screen. Many new computer games focus on reward systems where the gamers are constantly rewarded and at greater degrees each time they accomplish a task, the [[Stanford]] study provides evidence that video games can lead to addition because of the ecstasy of being rewarded.<ref>{{cite web | last =Brandt | first =Michelle | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Video games activate reward regions of brain in men more than women, Stanford study finds| publisher = Stanford Medical| date = 2008-02-08| url = http://med.stanford.edu/news_releases/2008/february/videobrain.html | doi = | accessdate = 2011-05-03}}</ref>
  â   â
===Variable Ratio Reinforcement===
  â
Dr. Maressa Hecht Orzack of Columbia stated in an interview with Jeremy Reimer that in her studies of Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Games or MMORPGs she concluded that they âtypically use what is known in psychological circles as [[variable ratio reinforcement]].<ref name="reimer">{{cite news|last=Reimer|first=Jeremy|title=Doctor claims 40 percent of World of Warcraft players are addicted|url=http://arstechnica.com/old/content/2006/08/7459.ars|accessdate=21 March 2011|newspaper=ARS Technica|date=August 2006}}</ref> Variable ratio reinforcement is the idea that the best way to optimize the desired behavior in the subject is to hand out rewards for correct behaviorâ Like mice that go for the same treat, [[World of Warcraft]] players keep playing the same dungeon over and over again to find the best armor or weapons for his/hers character. Orzack believes that the games are at fault more than the players.<ref name="reimer" />
  â   â
===Comorbidities===
  â
The percentage of [[comorbidity]] with internet or videogame addiction is also the subject of research and thus not known at this time. Mood disorders, attentional disorders, and substance dependencies are cited as comorbidities.

==Call for More Research==
  â
===MMORPG===
  â   â
In a 2007 report about the addictive nature of video games published by the AMAâs Council on Science and Public Health it also pointed to MMORPGs as a particular concern, indicating that although video game overuse can be associated with any type of game, it is most commonly seen among MMORPG players.
  â   â
Dr. Andrew Campbell, of the Brain and Mind Research Institute Clinical Centre at the University of Sydney, have looked closely at the factors that attract players to games where they are willing to give up other aspects of their life in order to play. âThe types of games these players were obsessed with were very popular titles that involved complex economies and merit systems,â Dr. Campbell said. âThey gave each player a sense of being skillful, clever, and part of a team or community. They also instilled in them a sense to continue with the game no matter how many rewards or âlevelsâ they attained in the game. More often than not, the players never thought about the end of a game, especially in a MMORPG world.â
  â   â
According to Dr. Campbell, research into video game addiction conducted from the early 1980s to the present has been contradictory on the seriousness of it. Some theorists believe that video game playing is an example of obsessive rather than addictive behavior, other theorists believe video game addiction could be as serious as gambling, alcoholism and even drug addiction.
  â   â
Dr. Campbell says that whether video game addiction exists, or whether it is merely obsessive behavior that is detrimental to the social and healthy development of gamers, the best treatment is prevention.
  â   â
It has been recommended for nurse practitioner psychotherapists, including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and other therapies that increase insight into a personâs behaviors. Doctors typically recommend psychopharmacology, the use of 12-step support groups, and other available addictions treatments.
  â   â
===Motivation===
  â   â
Richard M. Ryan, a psychologist and professor of psychology, psychiatry, and education at the University of Rochester in New York, has been focusing on a different aspect of video game addiction: motivation.<ref name="parker">{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Lauren|title=Gaming Addiction: The Real Story|url=http://www.gamespot.com/features/6207309/index.html|accessdate=23 March 2011|newspaper=Gamespot}}</ref> Ryan and his team are testing the idea that psychological needs for control, mastery, and connection can be readily satisfied within games.<ref name="parker" />
  â   â
Ryan and his team found that when games were played for less than 10 hours a week, there was no evidence of negative effects on wellness; when games were played in excess of 20 hours a week, signs of ill-being emergedânegative mood, symptoms of depression, and more impoverished relationships.<ref name="parker" /> The team's studies showed that those who overuse games are getting fewer of their needs satisfied in their lives outside of games.<ref name="parker" />
  â   â
"We also discovered players who report obsessive attitudes toward games--they are preoccupied with their games, feel compelled to play, and feel tension when they cannot or are not playing. This latter set of players also shows signs of negative effects on psychological functioning." <ref name="parker" />
  â   â
